There was one glimmer of good news about housing this week.
Nationally, sales of existing homes picked up for the first time since July.
That surprised most economists, and gave many new hope that we may be seeing the bottom of the real estate slump.
Now, before going any further, let's all repeat the old housing axiom, all real estate is local.
All real estate is local.
And with that in mind, here is a story from NPR's Ted Robbins, who toured some houses with real estate agents in Tucson, Arizona, where sales are up by double digits.
Ken Hoddack(ph) likes a loft in one of the bedrooms.
It gives it all kinds of extra space, and kind of a neat little niche for children.
Sandra Beacher(ph) hates the location.
My big downside is this house has no view, and that is really important for people.
Everybody moving out of the state, the number one item they list on the sheet I give them is view.
These real estate agents are a part of a group touring homes for sale in the Tucson suburb of Marana.
It's a way of networking and a way of giving feedback to the agent who has the listing - in this case, Cathy Waylan(ph).
At the half million dollar asking price, the sellers of this house will probably just break even after owning it for four years.
The comments from other agents will help Waylan explain that to her clients.
It helps us in talking with our sellers, and sometimes they can't grasp the whole reality of the market.
The reality is that it's a buyers market.
And in southern Arizona, buyers know it.
Sale prices are down, but existing home sales were up last month, nearly 20 percent from January, though they're still down from a year ago.
Cathy Waylan says buyers are returning but they are being really picky.
Everybody's looking for a deal, and everybody thinks that there's a better deal.
So, yeah, this is a great deal but I think there's probably a better one down the street next week.
In fact, down the street there is a better deal.
Waylan has a house listed for less than what owners paid.
They've defaulted on their mortgage and the bank decided to get what it could out of the property instead of foreclosing.
They're saying we'll take 300 even though the actual payoff is in the 370s.
It's worth it to us to sell that house and not have it on a foreclosure inventory.
Still, Waylan says she's had three contracts on the property fall through because buyers found something else they liked better.
